content: The "Federal Oil and Gas Reform Act of 1999" is cited as the short title. Section 109 of the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 is amended to include civil penalties for violations related to federal oil and gas royalties. Sec. 109 of the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 is amended to include civil penalties for violations related to federal oil and gas royalties, including failure to comply with royalty payment requirements or submitting false information. Violators may be liable for penalties up to 3 times the royalty amount. Sec. 109 of the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 now includes civil penalties for violations related to federal oil and gas royalties. Violators may be liable for penalties up to 3 times the royalty amount, plus interest, and a civil penalty of $25,000 per violation per day. Violations can be avoided if reported and corrected within 30 days. Additionally, lease administration violations include failure to notify the Secretary of designations or assignments under a lease. Any person who fails to comply with lease management responsibilities, including permitting entry, inspection, audit, notification of production, or providing necessary records, may be subject to a penalty of up to $10,000 per violation per day. Additionally, theft of oil or gas from a lease site is punishable by law. Any person who fails to comply with lease management responsibilities may face a penalty of up to $10,000 per violation per day. Theft of oil or gas from a lease site can result in a penalty of up to $25,000 per violation per day. Repeated violations will lead to notification and demand for compliance within 30 days, with failure to comply resulting in civil liability to the United States. Any person failing to comply with lease management responsibilities may face penalties. Non-compliance can lead to a demand for correction within 30 days, with civil penalties of 3 times the original amount. Repeated violations may result in production shutdown, acquisition prohibition, interest cancellation, or transfer in oil or gas leases. The Secretary can impose penalties for non-compliance with lease management responsibilities, including demanding corrections within 30 days and imposing civil penalties. Failure to comply may result in production shutdown, acquisition prohibition, interest cancellation, or transfer of oil or gas leases. The Secretary's determination of royalties or penalties is final unless appealed within 15 days. If an appeal is filed, a final decision will be made according to regulations. The Secretary can impose penalties for non-compliance with lease management responsibilities, including demanding corrections within 30 days and imposing civil penalties. Penalties can be deducted from any sums owed by the United States to the person charged. The Secretary may compromise or reduce civil penalties on a case-by-case basis. Notice of penalties will be served personally or by registered mail. The Secretary must provide reasons for penalty determinations on record. Judicial review is available for those who request a hearing within the specified time frame. Amounts received in actions for underpayment of royalties will be treated as royalties paid to the United States. Amounts received in actions for underpayment of royalties will be treated as royalties paid to the United States under the mineral leasing laws and the Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965. SEC. 3. SHARED CIVIL PENALTIES. Amendment to the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 to include trebled royalties or 50% of any civil penalty.
